review.title: Towards a Benchmark of Natural Language Arguments
review.abstract: The connections among natural language processing and argumentation theory are becoming stronger in the latest years, with a growing amount of works going in this direction, in different scenarios and applying heterogeneous techniques. In this paper, we present two datasets we built to cope with the combination of the Textual Entailment framework and bipolar abstract argumentation. In our approach, such datasets are used to automatically identify through a Textual Entailment system the relations among the arguments (i.e., attack, support), and then the resulting bipolar argumentation graphs are analyzed to compute the accepted arguments.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: In recent years, however, there has been an increase in interest in the subjects from formal and technical perspectives in artificial intelligence and a wide use of argumentation technologies in practical applications. However, such applications are always limited by the fact that arguments of natural language cannot be processed automatically by such argumentation technologies. Arguments are usually presented either as abstract nodes of a directed graph in which the edges represent the relationships of attack and support (e.g. in abstract argumentation theory (Dung 1995) and in bipolar argumentation (Cayrol and Lagasquie-Schiex 2005). Natural language arguments are commonly used in argumentation literature to provide ad-hoc examples of the understanding of rationality that is then introduced, but the need to find automatic ways of processing natural language arguments.

sections.heading: Natural Language Arguments: datasets
sections.text: Within a framework of application, we can divide this task into two successive sub-areas, namely i) the recognition of the semantic relationships between the parties in dispute in a debate (i.e. when one statement supports or attacks another), and reflecting all the arguments that are part of a debate and the acceptance of the semantic arguments. To reflect this separation into two sub-areas, we must describe each dataset that we describe in the following sub-areas.

sections.heading: Debatepedia dataset
sections.text: To build our first benchmark of natural language arguments, we have selected Debatepedia and ProCon, two encyclopaedias of pros and cons arguments on critical issues. To fill out the first level of the dataset, we have manually selected a series of topics (Table 2 Topics column) of the Debatepedia / ProCon debates, and for each topic we apply the following procedure: 1. the main question (i.e., the title of the debate in its affirmative form) is considered as the starting argument; 2. every user opinion is extracted and considered as an argument; 3. since attack and support are binary relationships, the arguments are paired with the following arguments: (a) the starting argument or (b) other arguments in the discussion, to which most current arguments are put forward.
